div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN BOOM
div.p: An interesting article, of which the fallowing are extracts, appears in the July number of Blackwoods magazine under the title of "The Egyptian Boom," by Sir R. Hamilton Lang, K.C.M.G : -

In this article I do not propose to enlarge upon the successful administration of Lord Cromer in Egypt. It is well known, and is it not written better than I could do in the brilliant pages of Lord Milner's 'England in Egypt,' and in the more stu'gy but tborougly reliable volume of Sir Auckland Colvin?

I am not the less an admirer of the strong, far-sighted, patiently persistent administrator who, so recently was obliged, from motives of health, to hand over to an experienced successor his heavy burden. Lord Cromer may rest from his labours assured that his great work in Egypt will follow him—work for which his country will ever be grateful.

I left Egypt in 1897, after ten years of continuous and active service there, and revisited it in the early months of this year with the desire to see with my own eyes, what I could only vaguely understand in London, the remarkable boom of prosperity which has come over that country during the past few years. What I saw, and the impressions left upon me, may perhaps interest the many in England who have only such a dim notion as I had of what had been going on in Egypt.

The charming residential town of Cairo of ten years ago I found disfigured by huge blocks of buildings five storeys high; enormous hotels built and building; where was then park is now studded with villas; tramways everywhere, even out to Cheops' Pyramid; motors careering along, followed by clouds of dust and heralded by the deafening sounds of horn or hoot. All the constructions are higgledy-piggledy without line or order. Huge ungainly blocks alongside of unpretentious residences; buildings being torn down or foundations being laid. The conversations over- heard were mostly of the price of plots of land, or the rise or fall of shares, or of companies floated or being floated, or of people who had become millionaires or expected to become such. One realised at once that one was amongst a community intoxicated with success, in the feverish escitement of speculation. The luxurious hotel, opened only some seven years before, was, while I was staying in it, sold to a company for £450,000. Its proprietor (the seller), reputed to be a millionaire, is laying the foundations of a still grander hotel, on a site which was once a prince's palace. Two wellauthenticated transactions will give a fair conception of the enormous rise in the value of property in the best parts of Cairo. A small villa, erected some twelve years ago at a cost of about £3000, found a purchaser recently at £32,000. A property purchased far £17,000 eight years ago was being treated for while I was in Cairo at £150,000. In fact, it is no exaggeration to say that property, in what was the residential part of Cairo, has increased in value, during the past five or six years, eightfold to tenfold. The price of land there may be said to vary from £46 to £82 per square metre (3 1/10 yards), equal to the value of land in the crowded parts of the city of London. In Alexandria a nearly similar appreciation in the value of town lands has taken place. Lands towards Gabari, which a few years ago were only of a nominal and prospective value, have recently changed hands at fabulous rates. The site of the Victoria College, bought about ten years ago for £1300, was sold at the beginning of this year for £100,000.

The origin or cause of this boom in the value of urban lands is traceable to the high price of cotton during recent years, and especially since 1903. When I left Egypt in April 1897 the price of cotton was 9 1/4 talleris per cantar ; in March 1907 it was worth 21 1/2 talleris. The average monthly value of cotton in the year 1896-7 was 9 1/2 talleris ; while the same average monthly value from 1st Sep- tember 1906 to April 1907 was 19 1/4 talleris.
The crop of cotton in 1896-7 was 5,875,597 cantars, and its value £11,163,634 ; that of 1906-7 is 7,000,000 cantars, of the value of £26,950,000.

Good cotton land in the Delta was worth, in 1897, about £40 per feddan (acre). Its worth to-day is £200. The acreage put yearly under cotton is roughly 1,200,000 feddans, the value of which has risen in the decade fivefold.

The comparisons which we have made above, refer to a period often years and eight months, but in reality the greatest increase in the value of cotton in Egypt has token place since 1902-3, say a period of four years.

Simultaneously with the boom of prosperity came a boom of speculation, which had its origin in the sale of the Daira Sanieh lands in 1898. Money was required by the Government to pay on a reliquat of expen- ses for the Sudan campaign, and three or four millions sterling were needed for the Assouan and Assiout Dams. The Caisse de la Dette refused to advance money for either purpose. In this situation a native Jewish banker, Mr. Raphael Snares, proposed to purchase the Daira Sanieh lands—about 400,000 acres,— engaging to pay off in 1905 the debt upon them, to make a cash advance of £500,000, and to share the profits in the enterprise with the Egyptian Government.

The undertaking being, however, too large for Mr. Snares alone, he addressed himself to his co-religionaire Sir Ernest Cassel. There was not much cause for hesitation on the part of that shrewd financier, as the administration of the Daira Sanieh, after paying expenses, taxes, and 5 per cent interest on its debt, had been yielding to the Egyptian Treasury a surplus of over £200,000 a year, which might safely be considered to represent a capital sum of three or four millions sterling. Sir Ernest Cassel became associated with Mr. Suares, and the bargain was concluded with the Egyptian Government. Sir Ernest Cassel also interested himself in finding the money needed for the dams.

div.head: Hashish Seizure
div.p: A seizure of 300 kilos of hashish was made yesterday morning by the Port Said coast guards.

div.head: Drowning Fatality
div.p: A certain Bayoumi Osman was accidentally drowned on Sunday morning while bathing in the Nile at Koubri el Ama.

div.head: The Polytechnic School
div.p: The Government has decided to build at Ghizeh five houses for the professors of the Polytechnic School at a cost of L.E. 20,000.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The new Alhambra Theatre will be opened on the 16th inst., the inaugurating play being the "Geisha," which will be staged by the Lombardo troupe.

div.head: Plague Bulletin.
div.p: During the last twenty-four hours the fol- lowing rasas were reported: 1 death in hospital at Alexandria and one recovery ; remaining under treatment 13 cases.

div.head: Spirit Lamp Explosion.
div.p: A young girl of some 5 years of age named Asina, living at Khalifa with her father, Cheikh Ahmen Haroun, moufti of Ghizeh, was very badly burnt by the explosion of a spirit lamp. The state of the child is very grave.

div.head: Port Said Development.
div.p: A native contemporary announces that Mouheb Pasha, Governor of the Suez Canal, is forming a company for the construction at Port Said of a casino and swimming baths, on similar lines to the casino at San Stefano.

div.head: New Government Buildings
div.p: A new mudirieh building is to be constructed at Mansourah, the capital of the Dakahlieh province, the cost of which is estimated at L.E. 40,000. The present Port Said police station is to be replaced next year by a new and larger building.

div.head: E.S.R. Cuide.
div.p: The States Railways are in course of pre- paring a general guide to Egypt which will be published next November ; this guide will be very exhaustive ; although naturally dealing principally with the system of the adminis- tration. The price will be P.T.5 per copy.

div.head: British Fireman Drowned.
div.p: The body of Patrick MacGoolaghan, fireman of S.S. "Roman Prince," was found in the water yesterday morning at the stern end of the ship. It is believed that the deceased fell overboard on Sunday night. The inquest, which is being held at the British Consulate, has not yet terminated.

div.head: Fire in Cairo
div.p: On Saturday evening at eleven o'clock a fire broke out in the shop of a liquor seller named Anastasa Elia in the Kasr el Nil quarter of Cairo. The fire brigade, assisted by the police, obtained the mastery of the confla- gration after four hours' work. The damage is estimated at L.E.2,000.

div.head: Military Furlough
div.p: The Cairo District Orders announce that Upper Egypt is now open for furlough. All non-commissioned officers and men returning from plague infected districts will be inspected for seven days after their return. Units will be responsible to have a representative at Cairo and Alexandria stations to meet men returning from Upper Egypt.

div.head: White Slave Traffic
div.p: It is very gratifying to note the activity which is prevailing in the suppression of this traffic. The French Consul, accompanied by the local police made a visit to a house of ill- repute in the Esbekieh quarter last Saturday and seized a young girl; her abductor was also placed under arrest. The girl will be sent home and the man will be expelled from the country. It is to be regretted that he cannot receive the punishment which he so richly deserves by a salutary course of exercise on the Tourah hills.

div.head: Railways Servants and Conscription.
div.p: The States Railways Administration has invited the Government to consider the question of relieving from military service those of their employees who are higher grade artisans and whose training necessitates a lengthy apprenticeship. The Administration emphasises the danger of having men entrusted with responsible positions who are insuffi- ciently trained and the consequent risk to the public safety. It seems very evident that it is hardly fair to a large administration to have its best hands taken for military service just at the moment when their services are be- coming valuable.

div.head:
NORTH EGYPT LAND CO. LTD.
SALE AT HAMMAM.
div.p: From the point of view of the shareholders of the North Egypt Land Company Limited a melancholy interest attaches to the sale of some of that Company's effects, which took place yesterday at Hammam in the Mariout district. The objects disposed of comprised horses, donkeys, mules, carts, wood, cement, etc., and the sale was conducted by a Maowen from Kafr Dawar by order of the authorities, as the Company owes about £280 to the Government. Very low prices ruled. An excellent donkey fell to one bidder for P.T. 520 and two good horses were knocked down for P.T. 620 each, while two mules fetched £16 apiece.

The North Egypt Land Company was regis- tered in May 1905. The directors were the Earl of Galloway, Sir Bradford Leslie, A. Durant, E. E. Pullman, Khalil Pasha Khayat and Lusena Bey. The capitalist £230,000 in a similar number of £1 shares. The object of the company was to acquire and develop a freehold estate in the Mariout district. This estate comprised about 14,500 feddans at Hammam. We extract the following from the prospectus : —"Taking a broad view of the whole matter, we feel that we can recommend the property, and that with a canal constructed and given sufficient water, your company formed to acquire and work the estate should prove a success.

"Early application will be made to the Egyp- tian Government, as recommended by Sir Douglas Fox and Partners in their report, for the extension of the Nubarieh Canal to irrigate the company's land with Nile water."

div.head:
BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui a midi).
div.p: Comme dans les seances precedentes, les affaires ont ete insignifiantes et limitees a quelques titres. Le tout n'aurait pas exige plus d'un quart d'heure pour etre conclu. Nous ne voyons pas dans ces conditions pourquoi I'ho raire a ete porte de 1 heure a 1 heure et demie. Quant aux fluctuations elles nont, bien entendu, ssans importance et representent plutot des cours nominaux.

La Cassa di Sconto donne toujours lieu a des pourparlers mais sans affaires effectives. Les pretentions des vendeurs teudent paralt il, a dimineur, puisque le prix s'inscrit a 45 francs, en baisse de 3 francs sur celui de vendredi dernier.

Les valeurs diregeantes profitent de la plus- value gagnee a Londres, sans toutefois attein- dre iei le meme niveau: L'Agricole se main- tient a 7 13/16 acheteurs; la National Bank s'avance de 19 5/8 19 13/16, la Delta Light de 9 a 9 1/8, I'Obligation Credit Foncier de 312 Fancienne at 264 1/2 la nouvelle a 314 et 265 respectivement.

Coomme le Credit Foncier, les Lots Turcs be neficient d'une plus-value notable. Leur cours progresse de 158 a 162; ce qui semble prouver que l'epargne cherche des placements plus stables que les valeurs nouvelles cependant offertes au rabais.

En hausse encore I'Alexandrria Water de 10 1/4 a 10 1/2, la Salt & Soda de 17/9 a 18, la Banque d'Athenes de 115 a 155 1/2, les Esta- tes de 21/32 a 11/16, I'Urbaine de 3 3/4 a 3 13/16, I'Union Fonciere de 4 3/4 a 4 13/16.

La Ramleh fleebit, au contraire, de 4 7/8 a 4 13/16, les jouissances Eaux du Caire de 184 a 180, les Markets de 25 a 24/6, la Delta Land de 1 11/16 a 1 5/8, I'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 22/6, a 21/6, le Comptoir de 3 a 2 3/4 l'action ancienne et de 2 7/8 a 2 5/8 la nouvelle, la Building Lands de 2 7/16 a 2 5/16, le Banco di Roma de 106 a 105 1/2, le Credit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/16 a 4, la Ban- que d'Orient de 115 1/2 a 115, l'Helouan de 7/16 a 3/8, la Zriffa de 3 1/2 a 3 3/8 l'action et de 8 a 7 la fondateur.
En United, qui a donne lieu a un nombre assez considerable de transactions, l'action ent un peu plus faible a 3/8, tandis que la patt de fondateur beneficie de 1/4 de livre a 2 1/4.

On a beaucoup resarque que l'Alexandria Water, qui etait en baisse continue depuis la mise a l'ordre du jour de la Commission Mu- nicipale de l'interpellation Fenderl an sujet de la nouvelle emission d'actions de cette so- ciete, reprend graduellemont depuis que la Commission, dans sa dernitre seance, a vote quiil n'y avait pas lieu de s'arreter aux obser- vations de M. Fenderl.

Il est question de nouveaux arrangements proposes par le Conseil d'Administration de la Bourse and Banking (Arditi). Comme cepen- dant les assertions sont contradictoires a ce sujet, nous attendrons de'etre exactement fixes sur la version officielle. Le comite des courtiers en valeurs s'occupe activement de cette mal heureuse affaire.

div.head:
THE GARIBALDI CENTENARY.
CELEBRATIONS IN CAIRO.
div.p: On Sunday the Italian Colony of Cairo fittingly celebrated the centenary of the birth of Garibaldi, their national hero. At seven o'clock punctually, a large concourse of Italians bearing national flags, a deputa- tion of the Greek community, and a dele- gation of the French Chamber, assembled in Ataba el Khadra Square to form the body of a procession, which was preceded by an international band. Among the as- sembly gathered to do honour to the mem- ory of Garibaldi we noticed many mem- bers of the Italian Philodramatic Society, the Societa dei Reduci delle Patrie Battaglie, composed of veterans of the War of Inde- pendence, the Societa Opersia Italians Cir- colo Operaio, Societa di Beneficenza, Gruppo Novelli, Seuola da Vinci, Unione Militare, the Italian Masonic Lodges and several other societies, whioh space precludes us from enu- merating.

The cortege, comprising several hundreds of people, paraded the principal streets of Cairo, and eventually stopped before the French Consulate, where the band struck up the "Marseillaise." In Kasr el Nil Square a congested throng of vehicles awaited the party, in order to drive them to the Civil Cemetery, where a magnificent demonstration took place. Here, Mr. Pasquale Isabella, the well known Italian lawyer, delivered an eulogistic address, which was met by a storm of applause. Later a memorial plate was unveiled and a deputy of the French Ma- sonic Lodge made a patriotic speech before presenting a crown of laurels. Dr. Yatron, on behalf of the Greek community, also con- tributed a wreath of laurels together with a few well chosen words of esteem for the memory of Garibaldi and the Italian nation. The party dispersed at about 11 o'clock, but reformed in the afternoon, and then proceeded to the Italian Schools, where ano- ther memorial plate was erected. After Mr. Taragni, of the Italian Philodramatic Society, had mode an excellent speech and many stirring songs had been delivered by the students, the scene of animated patriotism was transferred to Sheik Salama Theatre, where an amateur theatrical company gave an appropriate performance.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: On the occasion of the anniversary of the birthday of the Khedive on Friday next, the 12th inst., a register will on that day be placed at the disposition of persons desirous of signing their names therein on that day. The register will be at the office of the Master of Ceremonies, Ras el-Tin Palace.

div.head: THE CROMER GRANT CRITICIZED.
div.p: Mr. Philip Snowden, M.P., speaking at a miner's demonstration at Crumlin, Monmouth- shire yesterday, criticized the proposed grant to Lord Cromer for his services in Egypt, and pointed out that when Mr. Asquith was asked for money for old-age pensions he wanted to know where the money was to come from. Lord Cromer had for the past twenty-five years been taking from the taxpayers of the country £6,000 a year. Working men were told to be thrifty, but the men who were receiving £6,000 a year had no need to make provision for old age.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MOTOR BUSSES.
div.p: The Alexandria Tramway Company has been obliged to temporarily suspend its motor bus service from Mohamed Aly Square to Ras-el Tin. The reason of this step is solely due to the necessity of having to repair the 'rubber tyres of the busses, which have been prematurely worn out owing to the state of the route along the quay. As soon as it was discovered that the wear and tear suffered by the rubber was proceeding at an abnormally rapid rate the company immediately sent to Europe for a fresh stock of tyres. At the present time the manufacturers of automobile tyres in Europe have a huge amount of orders to cope with and some delay has therefore ensued. The service will be resumed on the Ras-el Tin line as soon as the tyres arrive.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman liner Flavian sailed from Malta last evening for Tripoli and Alexandria.
The S.S. British Prince, with passengers and general cargo, arrived at Manchester on the 6th inst from Alexandria via Malta.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Nous rappelons que Samedi prochain la veille du 14 Juillet aura lieu la grande fete de nuit au Casino San Stefano. Cette fete séra certainement une des plus grandes attractions de la saison estivale à San Stefono, grâce aux préparatifs que la direction est en train de faire. La terrasse qui a été agrandie de beau- coup cette année, sera entièrement illuminée a la Vénitienne. Il y aura de même de très inté- ressantes projections cinématographiques en plein air. Le fameux orchestre Bracale aidé de l'excellente fanfare Italienne d'Alexandrie exécuteront alternativement les morceaox les plus choisis et pour terminer, grand feu d'ar- tifice qui promet d'étre d'une beauté excep- tionnelle, ayant été commandé dans une des meilleures usines pyrotechniques de France.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible ofr the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: THE SUDAN AS THE BRITISH BASE FOR EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,—The above title to my letter will strike some readers as somewhat peculiar, but the idea is by no means far fetched, and it is believed that behind the soenee a steady movement is going in the South for the overrunning of Egypt from that quarter at the least sign of trouble here, and not with Egyptian troops. From a well informed source it has been ascertained that steady recruiting is going on in the Sudan with, it was gathered, the eventual attainment of a strong majority of Sudanese troops over Egyptian, both in Egypt and the Sudan, and further it was averred that Sudanese troops would by degrees be substituted in Egypt for the "Gippy", whose destination would be "down south" and, in parenthesis, out of mischief. A still more interesting item in a most interesting programme is the creation of a Camel Corps of British soldiers, and I was assured that this was being carried out with considerable despatch.

It is evident that Great Britain's extremely ambiguous position here will sooner or later demand a solution and final decision : the position is logically untenable and calls for a practical settlement to which end there are two courses open. The abandonment to its own dices of this country would be most sure- ly eventually proved more than indefensible, in fact reprehensible, and the results of such abandonment would reflect very little credit on Great Britain, to put it mildly, and things would be indeed shameful if after the British left Egypt to look after and govern herself, one of the Powers was obliged to step in and restore order: because England had washed her hands of the country after having risked valuable lives and enormous capital.

The other course is too manifest to need remark, but a perusal of these few lines should show the careful observer that England is not such a fool as so many people think, and that despite party politics and agitators, a true and forcible illustration of the survival of the fittest will eventually result, and it is more than possible that the change will be effected in such a manner that most people will be distinctly and agreeably surprised to wake one fine morning and find themselves British subjects in the most pleasant manner, without even applying lor a Consular certi- ficate.
I am, Sir, Yours Truly

div.head: ENGLISH FOR EGYPTIANS.
div.p: "A thousand and our Grammar Questions" has been announced as being in preparation some years ago, but illness compelled the author to lay it aside when only a few pages had been written, and since then his health has seldom permitted him to attempt any work outside his daily routine as a school-master and editor of "The Oriental Scholar Magazine." This glossary of grammar questions and answers has been written to supply a want often felt by candidates preparing for examina- tions in English Grammar in general. It is not intended to supersede the careful study of any of the excellent manuals now in use, but to serve the purposes of a handy book of reference. Almost every examination paper in this subject contains at least four questions, and experience has proved that the answers to such questions are often most unsatisfactory. Even when students have carefully read the text-book, they frequently show serious ina- bility to apply their knowledge to the questions set, many essential poruta being overlooked.
We have also received the first form gram- mar and analysis by the same author.
This work is divided into two parts. The first for the first primary year pupils, the second for the second primary year pupils.

The examples and the exercises have been chosen with great care, and will be found to contain instances of all the commoner constructions. The Arabic of some definitions and the difficult words found in every lesson is also given. The method of analysis adopted in this book has been tried with boys between the ages of nine and twelve years, and the results have been satisfactory.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Ronald Graham will act as H.B.M.'s Diplomatic Agent and Consul General during the absence of Sir Eldon Gorst.
Mr. H. Boyle has left for England.
Mr. Webb, acting Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works, will go on leave on the 15th inst.
Mr. Williams, Inspector General of Irriga tion, Lower Egypt has been granted leave of absence for two months and twenty days as from August 15th.
During the absence on leave of Ismail Pasha Sirri, Mr. Ireland, of the second circle of Irrigation, will replace his Excellency.
Judge Bond has left for Europe on holiday.

Dr. Schiess Pasha, being unable to reply personally to the many kind friends who offered their condolences at the sad loss of his wife, desires us to express his heartfelt appreciation of the sympathy extended to him.
Mr. Maspero is shortly going on three month's leave of absence, which he will spend in France.

Sir Horace Pinching will go on leave for three and a half months on August 15th. On his return he will take advantage of his right to a pension and go on the board of administration of the Cairo Sand Brick Company.

Dr. Graham Bey, who will replace Sir Horace Pinching, will go on leave on the 12th inst. and attend the Hygienic Conference to be held at Vienna at the end of September as delegate of the Egyptian government.
Piot Bey, Chief Veterinary Surgeon to the Alexandria Municipality, has been granted three and a half months' leave. During his absence his work will be done by M. Tebonille.
Miralai Sir H.B. Hill, Bart., Bey, Sudan Government has been decorated by the Khedive with the 3rd class Order of the Osmanieh.
The Rev. R. MacInnes is leaving for England on holiday.
Mr. and Mrs. John Carr, of Chawa Domains, are leaving by the S.S. "Britannia" for London and will be absent until the end of September.

Lieutenants J.B.W. Pennyman, H. Forbes, and H.C.B. Kirkpatrick, all of the King's own Scottish Borderers have passed in subjects a and b for promotion at the examination held at Cairo on the 27th ult.

div.head: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Lundi 8 juillet.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres s'est maintenu a 3 3/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé samedi passé de 1/8 a 84 1/2 et l l'Unifiée de 1/2 à 101. La Na- tional Bank a avancé de 1/8 à 20. L'Agricole, qui avait perdu 1/8 vendredi a 7 7/8, l'a rat- trapé le lendemain a 8. La Daira Sanieh est demeurée inchangée à 13 1/2. La Delta Light a bénéficié de 1/8 à 9 1/4.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perdu 2 francs vendredi, mais en a regagné 8 samedi, soit en reprise de 6 francs à 686. La Banque d'Athènes est renseignée en avance de 3 francs à 118.

Malgré la meilleure tenue des places diri- geantes d'Europe et malgré le fait indéniable que l'horizon local tend de plus en plus a s'é- claircir, notre marché n'a guère brillé, ce matin, par l'entrain. Il est vrai que la morte saison commence a battre son plein et qu'il serait. passablement extravagant de s'attendre, en ce moment, à un gros courant d'affaires. Au sur- plus, il est de coutume de se montrer réservé an début de la semaine, d'attendre le vent qui soufflera de Londres et de Paris, depuis que les effets de la crise nous ont placés sous la dépen- dance directe des marchés d'Occident.

Mais, pour avoir été inactive, la séance n'a. ese nullement mauvaise. La tendance generale a ete meme ferme et on a remarque que les offres étaient loin de présenter le volume de ces jours derniers. C'est d'un bon présage, et il y a lieu de s'attendre à un. raffermissement a bref délai, d'autant plus que les evenements s'attachent a donner des démentis constants aux prédictions das pessimistes a outrance.

Dans le comparitment des Banques, la Na- tional a avance a 19 11/16-8/4. L'Agricole s'est rafermie a 7 13/16. La Banque d'Orient est revenue a 111. La Cassa di Sconto est restee stationnaire a 50 l'action ancienne et 60 la nouvelle ; la reouverture des guichets de
cet establissement de credit est un fait accom- pli depuis vendredi soir a Alexandrie et depuis ce matin au Caire.

Le Crédit Foncier a ete négligé à 680 ; l'o- bligation a lots ancienne à progresse a 311 ; par contre, la nouvelle a faibli à 262. Le Wardan Estate a fléchi à 5 1/4. L'Allotment est retombé à 1 7/8-15/16.
Les Jouissances Esux du Caire ont baisse à 180 et les Automobiles à L.E. 2.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Egyptian ont été bien tenus à 4 3/8. Les autres titres du compartiment sont restés à leurs prix précédents.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les New Egyptian se sont alourdis à 14 sh.6 et les Abdy à 0 7/16. Les Markets ont avancé a 24 sh.3.
Nous détachons d'une correspondance dé Londres, en date du 2 Juillet lé passage suivant :

"La situation monétaire n'est pas cequ'elle devrait être à la fin d'un semestre. En d'au- tres termes, l'argent devrait être plus abon- dant ayec l'immense rentrée des dividendes de Juillet Toutefois, à Lombard Street, les taux d'escompte ont sérieusement baissé. Le "Stan- dard" fait remarquer à ce propos, qu'il reste à voir si les banquiers qui spéculent sur un abais- sement du loyer de l'argent ne vont pas trop loin dans leurs prévisions, mais que, pour l'instant, la plupart des facteurs sont défavo- rablés a ceux qui s'efforcent dé maintenir les taux d'escompte à leur niveau actuel.

"Au Stock Exchange, des velléités de re- prise ont pu être constatées cette semaine. C'est M. Asquith qui a donné le signal de ce mouvement en déclarent que, cette année, le gouvernement ne demanderait au marché mo- nétaire tout au plus qu'un million de livres sterling sur des bons à courte échéancé. A cette annonce rassurante se sont joints des avis favorables du çontinent et des Etats-Unis. On raconte, en outre, qu'un vaste syndicat de la Cité s'est formé pour soutenir le marche et qu'il a groupé dans ce but une trentaine de millions sterling.

"Quoi qu'il en soit de cette intervention, il est certain que les achats de placement ont reparu en bon nombre et se sont spécialement étendus à des valeurs fort malmenées tout ré- cemment encore, entre autres aux bons titres égyptiens, qui sont réellement à des cours tentants.
"La liquidation s'est effectuée sans aucun embarras, avec des reports fort peu différents des précédents."

On sait que l'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Société Anonyme du Béhéra, tenue le 19 Mars dernier, avait approuvé la distribu- tion, à tître de dividende extraordinaire, des 50,000 actions privilégiées 5 % de £5 restées a la souche, soldé des 100,000 créées en vertu de la délibération de l'assemblée générale ex- traordinaire du 14 Mars 1905.
Or, on annonce d'Alexandrie que ces actions privilégiées jouissance du 1er Juillet 1907, seront délivrées aux actionnaires de la Béhéra, une pour une, à partir du 15 du mois conrant.

Les recettes de la Delta Light Raitways Co. pour la semaine au 23 Juin dernier ont été de L.E. 4,234 contre 4,006 en 1906, soit en aug- mentation de L.E. 228. Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Avril 1907 se chiffrent par L.E. 60,002 contre 49,028 pour l'exercice pré- cédent, soit en majoration de L.E. 10,974.

ORDRE DU JOUR.
1. Approbation et ratification du projet de modification des Articles I (para. 2) VI & VII de l'Acte de Concession de Mai 1897.

Le Président du Conseil d'Administration, Baron GEORGES DE REUTER.

div.head: The Egyptian Delta Light Railways, LIMITED.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the ANNUAL ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the Company will be held in Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad Street in the City of London, on Tuesday, 23rd July, 1907, at 3 o'clock p.m. precisely, for the purpose of receiving the Directors' Report and Balance Sheet for the year ended 31st March, 1907, electing Directors in the place of the three retiring by rotation, appointing Auditors for the ensuing year and fixing their renumeration, declaring a Dividend, and transacting the Ordinary General Business of the Company, and also for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit passing, with or without modification, the following Resolu- tion then intended to be proposed, that is to say :-
RESOLUTION.

"That the Board of Directors be authorised to enter into an Agreement on behalf of the Company with the Egyptian Government modifying the Deed of Concession for the Helouan Railways and Schedule of Condi- tions dated 30th April, 1888, in the form now submitted to the Meeting and signed by the Chairman for the purpose of identification subject to any modifications or alterations to such Agreement as the Beard may deem desirable."
By Order of the Board, F. J. H0RNE Secretary.
The agreement above referred to may be inspected at the Office of the Company at any time during business hours prior to the Meeting.
211, GRESHAM HOUSE, OLD BROAD STREET, LONDON, E.C. 4th July, 1907.

N.B.—Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the General Meeting of the Company, they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants either in London at the Registered Office of the Company or at any London Clearing House Bank, or at the London Office of the National Bank of Egypt, the Bank of Egypt, the Anglo- Egyptian Bank, Limited, Credit Lyonnais, or the Imperial Ottoman Bank, two clear toys before the tote of the Meeting, i.e., not later than the 20th July, or in Egypt with any of the last-mentioned Banks ten clear days before the date of the Meeting. i.e., not later than 12th July, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held. Certificates of Deposit to be signed by the depositees in exchauge for the Share Warrants so lodged, which must be produced by the holders attending the Meeting, may be obtained upon applica- tion to the London or Cairo Offices of the Company. Should Shareholders wish to vote by proxy the Certificate of Deposit must be sent in to the Company's Office attached to the Proxy Form at least 48 hours before the General Meeting is held.
Dividend Warrants will be issued on the 26th July 1907.

div.head:
AMERICA'S NAVAL MOVEMENTS.
JAPAN'S ATTENTION EXCITED.
PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT AGRESSIVE.

div.p: Useful work is quietly proceeding in putting the navy and coast defences of the Pacific into as good condition as appropriations permit. A drydock is being constructed at Puget Sound. It is expected that a special effort will be made to dredge the channel of the Mare Island navy yard and make it accessible for heavy battle- ships. It is rumoured that Mr. Root during his forthcoming visit to Mexico will negotiate for the purchase of a site for a naval station at Magdalena Bay (Lower California). (Reuter)
The transfer of the battleship fleet to the Pacific has excited the attention of Japan.

President Roosevelt, through Rear-Admiral Brownson, declares that he proposes to give the world a somewhat startling demonstration of what the American navy is capable of doing to protect either or both coasts of the United States. There is no time, he says, like the present for such a demonstration when the United States is at perfect peace with every nation. (Reuter)

div.head:
ROYAL INSIGNIA STOLEN.
KING'S RECEPTION POSTPONED.

div.p: The preparations for the King's visit to the City has revealed the fact that the Royal Insignia of the Order of St. Patrick, which was kept in Dublin Castle, has been stolen. It is valued at £50,000. The King's reception of the Knights of St. Patrick and the investiture of Lord Castletown, which was to have taken place on Wednesday, has been postponed. (R.)

div.head:
KING EDWARD'S TOUR.
AN EXTENSIVE PROGRAMME.

div.p: The King and Queen have started on a week's tour in North Wales, Ireland, and South Wales. They will lay the foundation stone of a University college in Bangor, visit the Dublin Exhibition and open the new dock at Cardiff. (Reuter)

div.head:
ZANZIBAR COAST STRIP.
LEGAL STATUS OF SLAVERY.

div.p: House of Commons. Mr. Winston Church- ill, replying to Sir Charles Dilke, said that the legal status of slavery along the Zanzibar coast-strip would be abolished on 1st Octo- ber. The House of Commons would be asked to vote compensation. (Reuter)

A fire was discovered on Saturday on board the "Hoche" at Toulon. This is the third unexplained fire on board battleships at Tou- lon within a month. Much anxiety is felt throughout the country. (Reuter)
22 anarchists, including foreigners, have been arrested at Barcelona They are suspected of being implicated in a terrorist plot. (Reuter)
Two thousand peasants tried to destroy the works for the substitution of mechanical trac- tion on the banks of the Ladoga The police wounded ten. (Havas)

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
THE LANGUAGE QUESTION.

div.p: The multiplicity of proposals, the difficulties of the language question, the length of the speeches, and the unpreparedness regarding procedure is rendering the labours of the Conference excessively prolonged and com- plicated. Expert observers are beginning to doubt whether much beyond some extension of the principle of arbitration will be the outcome of the Conference. (Reuter)
A Yellow Book on Macedonia was presented to Parliament to-day, and one on the custom dues of Turkey.
The Chamber has approved the law for the dismissal of the 1903 class, but rejected, by 385 votes against 366, the motion including in it the mutinous soldiers who have been sent to Gafsa.
Commandant Dreyfus has requested his retiring pension. (Havas)

The members of the Korean deputation declare that their credentials have been signed and sealed by the Emperor, but as the latter is a prisoner of the Japanese he is unable to admit the truth for fear of the consequences. (Reuter)
The Governor of Anhui is dead. He died from a revolver shot, not a bomb explosion. His assailant has been captured. (Reuter)

div.head: EGYPTIAN HOTELS.
"RAPID AND REMARKABLE PROGRESS"
div.p: The tenth annual general meeting of the Egyptian Hotels, Ltd., was held on the 1st July 1907 at the offices of the company, 11, Ironmonger-lane, E.C., Lord Claud Hamilton, Chairman of the company, presiding.
The notice convening the meeting and also the report of the auditors having been read by the Assistant Secretary,

The Chairman said: Gentlemen, — It is sel- dom that a Board of Directors is in the happy position of presenting to shareholders accounts which show, within about ten years of the in- corporation of a company, a more rapid and remarkable progress than that indicated in the report and accounts of the Egyptian Ho- tels, Ltd., now in your hands. We started with a debenture debt of £280,000, of which £230,000 was offered to the public, but was left very largely on the underwriters' hands, and with our ordinary shares »t a very nomin- al value. In the brief period which has elapsed since then, we have been able to redeem, partly by the operation of the sinking fund, but chiefly through the realisation of surplus lands on our Ghezireh estate, no less than £141,400 of our debentures, leaving the total outstanding debenture debt at the pre- sent time at £138,600. This extraordinary development is due to a combination of caus -es, of which I will indicate two or three. Firstly, the prosperity that has attended our company could not have been realised but for the able administration of affairs in Egypt by Lord Cromer, and the stability secured under the protection afforded by the British Govern- ment The productions of the country have shown great expansion, and this has reacted on the prosperity of the people and the revenues of the Government and has been accompanied by the investment of large sums of European capital in Egypt The effect of this has been a great increase in the value of land in Cairo and elsewhere in Egypt, and in this increase we have had the good fortune to share. When we took over the Ghezireh domain there was in- cluded in it a large area of surplus land in the neighbourhood of Ghezireh Palace. The sale of a part of this surplus land has realised a net sum altogether of over £250,000, of which we have still to receive a sum of £120,000. We have yet in our possession at Ghezireh an area of 78,000 square metres of land, including that on which the Ghezireh Palace Hotel stands, situated on and near the Nile, in what has become a very fashionable suburb of Cairo, which will on the opening of the new bridge across the Nile, opposite our property, be within a few minutes' tram ride of the centre of Cairo. Those who are acquainted with the value of land in Cairo will realise what is the total value of 78,000 square metres of land in such a position. I am informed by the directors resident in Cairo that the land has quadrupled in value in the last four years. This estimate is in addition to the value of Ghezireh Palace Hotel bails lings and their equipment, and the value of the Shepheard's Hotel property. Secondly, the undoubtedaalubrity of the climate of Egypt the Oriental scenery and customs, and the interest attaching to the monuments of Egypt, have combined to attract vast num- bers of visitors annually from all nations. This has, of course, greatly increased the demand for hotel accomodation.
"THE WORLD WIDE REPUTATION OF THE HOTELS."

Thirdly, the world-wide reputation of our hotels, which, thanks to the able manage- ment of Mr. Baehler with his staff of assist- ants, was never greater than it is to-day, coupled with the comfort they afford and the careful attention given to the cuisine and to sanitation, has largely increased our revenues, so that the profits of the hotels, after charging all costs of working and main- tenance, now reach a sum of £47,995 10s 8d, against £22,304 certified by the audi- tors in the debenture prospectus issued in 1897. But, gentlemen, it is only right that I should remind you that the Board would not have been in a position to have fully availed themselves of the advance in the prosperity of Egypt, to which I have allud- ed, had it not been for the invaluable advice and assistance they have always re- ceived from Mr. Peat, at one time the sec- retary, and now one of the directors of the company. In the earlier days of the company's history, ami especially during the negotiations for terminating the working ar- rangements with the Compagnie Internation- ale dee Grands Hotels, the financial abil- ity and unfailing courage of Mr. Peat alone made it possible for the Board to overcome the difficulties with which they were then confronted, and to achieve the position on which they are to-day able to congratulate the shareholders. As pointed out in the di- rectors' report, our property, after the re- ceipt of the £120,000 referred to above, and the payment off of the outstanding deben- tures. will consist of Ghezireh Palace Hotel with its furniture and equipment, 78,000 metres of land at Ghezireh, including that on which the hotel stands, Shepheard's Ho- tel and its equipment, with a lease having 65 years to run at a rent of £1,850 per annum. These assets are available to meet liabilities and capital, together estimated at a total figure of £280,000, as shown in the directors'report. As regards the acoounts, there is little to add to what may be seen from the accounts themselves. The addition to land, buildings and plant include the purchase of the German dairy, the milking of new roads at Ghezireh, the addition of a third storey at Shepheard's Hotel and the necessary equip- ment, and the enlargement of the dining room and grill room at Shepheard's Hotel. I may remark that the additional storey at Shepheard's Hotel has increased our accommodation by 100 beds, making it now 510 beds.
INCREASED PROFITS.

The profits of the hotels alluded to above, and amounting to £47,995 10s 8d, compare with a figure of £45,168 10s 7d in the previous year, representing an increase of £2,827 Os 1d. Our net profits are £30,234 19s 2d, as against £27,098 Os 1 11d in the previous year, an increase of £3,141 18s 3d. On the complete amortisa- tion of the debentures and the compensation paid to the Comapgnie Internationale des Grands Hotels there will be a relief to the profit and loss account of more than £15,000 per annum. I now beg to more : "That the report and accounts for the year ended 30th April, 1907, as submitted to the shareholders, be received and adopted."
Mr. E. A. Harrison seconded the motion, which was carried unanimously.

The Chairman next moved : "That divi- dends of 5 per cent, on the preference shares and 20 per cent on the ordinary shares of the company for the year ended 30th April, 1907, be and the same are hereby declared payable on and after Tuesday, the 2nd July, 1907."
Mr. JJ. Hug seconded the motion, which was carried.
The Chairman next moved the re-election of Messrs W. B. Peat and Em. C. Zervudachi, the retiring directors, which was seconded by Mr. Baehler and carried.

Mr. W.B. Peat: I now beg to move: "That the shareholders desire to record their high appreciation of Mr. Charles Baehler's able management of the hotels and of the assistance rendered him by his staff." I ought to say just a word or two iu proposing that. I have had the advantage this year of being in Egypt and seeing our directors there, particularly making myself acquainted with the hotel and also seeing the new storey which has been added to it. My previous experience of going to Egypt was a year or two before, on which occasion I accompanied his Lordship. Upon my recent visit I found vast improvements in the hotel, not only in the structure, but also in the furniture, the cooking, the materials supplied, and, in fact, in everything which makes life, to a visitor, comfortable and con- venient. All that has been done under the able direction of Mr. Baehler, who is the life and soul of the place. I therefore have very great pleasure in moving the resolution which I have read.

Mr. Harrison : As a resident director in Egypt it affords me very great pleasure to testify to the complete accuracy of every word that Mr. Peat has said. I have lived in the hotel myself now for the last thirteen years, and therefore am more or less competent to express an opinion founded on experience, and I therefore cordially second the motion which Mr. Peat has submitted to you.

The Chairman : In putting that resolution I would like to say that, although I have not had the advantage of being in Egypt dnring the last few years, I have heard on all sides of the great ability shown by Mr. Baehler incon- ducting these hotels, and of his universal courtesy, which has earned for him popularity with every visitor who enters the hotel. I think aw are exceedingly fortunate in having a gentleman of such position to manage our affairs in Egypt. (Hear, hear).
The vote was unanimously accorded, and, on the motion of Mr. A. Wright, seconded by Mr Baehler, Messrs Turquand Youngs and Co. were reappointed auditors.

Mr. Harrison proposed a vote of thanks to the Chairman for the great assistance he had rendered in the interests of the company since its formation, and also for presiding, and this having been seconded by Mr Hug and carried, the proceedings terminated.

div.head: THE OXFORD PAGEANT.
div.p: London, July 1.

The pageant which is at present being per- formed on the banks of the Cherwell at Oxford may fairly be said to be the most perfect representation of its kind that has as yet been given in England ; and now that pageants have become so fashionable and attracted such keen attention and competition, this is no small boast for Oxford to be able to make. The old University City lends itself peculiarly well to this form of enterprise ; tor it has a romance about it possessed by no other town, save perhaps its sister on the Cam, a romance blended of reverend age and perennial youth to which all who know it fall enchanted vic- tims ; it can boast too an historical past of more than usual interest, for within and around its walls epoch-making events in politics, science, and art have taken place ; and further it possesses a scenic beauty and adaptibility surpassed by none. Consequently it is not to be wondered and that all competent critics proclaim the Oxford pageant to be the pageant per excellence of modern times.

The spot chosen is the corner where the Cherwell divides just short of Magdalen Bridge, and there a stand spanning the tongue of land has been erected, capable of holding some 3000 people, from which one looks forth on to an entrancing scene of river, meadows and the old City walls and gateway beyond.

The representations or scenes given amount to 16 and take in all some three hours to per- form. They run chronologically, commencing with the legend of Saint Frideswide, circa A.D. 727, around which the origin of the City hangs, and ending with a glimpse of St. Giles' fair in the reign of George III, circa 1785. It would of course be impossible to attempt any descrip- tion of the individual scenes in the space of a short article; enumerated they are as follows:—

The legend of Saint Frideswide, circa A.D. 727. The coronation of Harold Harefoot, A.D. 1036. The beginnings of the University. circa A.D. 1110 King Henry II gives a charter to the City Of Oxford, circa A.D. 1160. Friar Bacon, circa A.D. 1270. St Scholastica's day, A.D. 1354. Masque of the Medieval Curricu- lum. Wolsey receives Henry 8th at Oxford, A.D. 1518. Funeral of Amy Bobsart, A.D. 1560. State progress of Queen Elizabeth, A.D. 1566. Visit of James 1, A.D. 1605. Charles 1st at Oxford. The happy days A.D. 1636. Charles 1st at Oxford. The early days of the Civil War, A.D. 1643. Charles 1st at Oxford. The surrender of Oxford, A.D. 1646. Expulsion of the fellows of Magdalen by James 1st, A.D. 1687. Scene in the 18th century.

Some of the scenes deserve particular praise but all were good ; nothing had been spared in trouble or expense to secure historical ac- curacy or scenic effect. Perhaps the most unique and attractive scene was the masque of mediaeval learning, for which the author de- serves all praise, for in conception as well as execution it was as pleasing and beautiful a piece of symbolism as it has ever been my good fortune to witness. The theme in short is this—a student in search of Good Learning is received by the Seven Liberal Arts and the Three Philosophies. He makes his choice be- tween Theology, Law and Medicine, and with some reluctance chooses Theology ; but his companion is lured aside by the Pleasure and Joy of Life, and fells a victim to the Tempta- tions which assail youth. The music and dancing or pleasure's minions was as exquisite as their costumes, and I confess that I felt more than a sneaking sympathy with the student who threw in his lot with them.

But I might wander on at length describing the gorgeous effects of the varying scenes, some pompous, such as the kingly episodes, others humourous, such as the Town and Gown riot on St Scholastica's day, while others again, such as Amy Robsart's funeral, touched a deeper chord. Suffice it to say that each seemed to go by only to he surpassed by that which followed ; and when at the grand finale the entire body of performers, numbering I should think some 2000 souls and ranging from the merest babes to aged and reverend sires massed in a brilliant human parterre and joined in one swelling chores of "O God, our help in ages past" one felt that there was something more than mere passing pageantry, some insight into the inner meaning of Oxford's glorious past.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement
div.p: OF THE
"Egyptian Gazette."

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaust- ive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton need, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt- for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
VOYAGES D'ETE A PRIX REDUITS.
div.p: La Khedivial Mail Line mettra en vente a ses Agences d'Alexandrie, du Caire et de Port Said des billets speciaux d'aller et retour qui permettront aux personnes desireuses de se rafrachir par un petit voyage en Grece, a SMYRNE, METELIN, CONSTANTINOPLE ou en SYRIE, de le faire a un taux reduit pendant les mois de JUILLET et AOUT.
La nourriture pendant deux jours de qua- rantaine est comprise dans ces prix.

Des prix reduits seront accordes aux passa- gers par plusiers hotels a Costantinople, comme aussi an Phalere, Athenes, etc., et si les passagers en premiere classe desirent rester a bord a Constantinople et retourner par le meme vapeur, ils auront la faculte de le faire en payant Fcs. 10 par jour pour leur nour- riture.

Pour la Sylie on emettrs. egalement des billets speciaux su prix du voyage simple pour le voyage de l'aller et de retour. Le prix du voyage d'Alexandrie a Beyrouth et retour sera done L.E. 3,500 par personne en premiere classe et L.E. 2,600 en deuxieme classe.
CONDITIONS.
Les billets pour ces voyages ne pourront etre obtenus qu'aux Agences de la Compagnie a Alexandrie, Port-Said et au Caire (Bonded Stores).
Les billets seront strictement personnels et aucune autre reduction ne sera accordee.

La duree de la validite des billets est de trois semaines a compter de l'arrivee au port de destination. Leur validite ne peut pas etre prolongee sauf contre paiement de la difference entre le prix de ces billets et celui des billets ordinaires.
Les passagers munis de ces billets n'auront pas la faculte de s'arreter dans les ports inter- inediaires.
Alexandrie, le 14 juin 1907. 30586-14-4

div.head: Sudan Government
